snippet: With temperatures expected to soar on Sunday, more than a million people remained without power after deadly thunderstorms tore through the mid-Atlantic region.
abstract: About two million Washington DC-area residents remain without electricity after a deadly string of thunderstorms whipped through the mid-Atlantic region; storms downed trees and power lines, killing at least 12 people; emergency workers urge residents to look after their elderly neighbors, warning that temperatures are again likely to soar into the triple digits.

byline.original: By SHERYL GAY STOLBERG and MARC SANTORA
byline.contributor: Sheryl Gay Stolberg reported from Washington, and Marc Santora from New York. Reporting was contributed by Emmarie Huetteman from Washington; Mark Landler from Bethesda, Md.; Colin Moynihan and Michael Schwirtz from New York; Peter Khoury from Philadelphia; and Nick Bilton from San Francisco.

lead_paragraph: With temperatures expected to soar on Sunday, more than a million people remained without power after deadly thunderstorms tore through the mid-Atlantic region.

headline.main: After Storms in Mid-Atlantic, Stifling Heat and Power Loss
headline.print_headline: Storms Trailed by Power Loss and Stifling Heat
